newsitem.title: GERMANY: Strauss-Kahn confident of French marks for EMU.
newsitem.headline: Strauss-Kahn confident of French marks for EMU.

text.p: France will make great strides this year to reduce its deficit and qualify for Europe's planned single currency, French Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn said in an interview with the weekly Die Zeit.

Strass-Kahn said in a text of the interview made available ahead of publication on Thursday, that France's budget deficit could be lower than the Maastricht target of three percent of GDP this year, and that Portugal, Italy and Spain would likely be in the first wave of economic and monetary union (EMU) in 1999.

"One thing is certain: We will ensure that our deficit falls 0.4 percent. Thanks to accelerated economic growth we could come very close to three percent -- perhaps even below it," Strauss-Kahn was quoted as saying.
"So when the selection of the euro members is made in the spring of 1998 we will be in as good form as our EU partners."

The Maastricht treaty on monetary union requires participants to meet a range of fiscal targets in 1997 to qualify for EMU in 1999. Among the most important is limiting budget deficits to three percent of gross domestic product.

Strauss-Kahn said the French economic audit, which this week revealed a deficit of 3.5-3.7 percent of GDP, could only be seen as a forecast but that Paris would introduce measures to reduce the budget deficit.
He added that the deficit alone was not the most important fiscal target for monetary union.
"For reasons that I cannot explain all attention is currently on the deficit criterion. All the criteria are important," he said.

"It is more important to me that our economies converge and that regarding the deficit in the long term we approach acceptable levels. Only then will we be able to link ourselves together with a common currency," he added.
